Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and if there are no valid notarizations, the local node can rely on the dpowconfs method to detect there is some network event happening

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/komodo/dPOW-conf.html

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: recent discussions show that more confusion can be created by notaries if they ignore the delay, so I am considering adding the delay requirement to the consensus rules.

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: How do nodes determine the dpos-conf number? That'd require going off of the GC chain right? Like using a block explorer or that SPV method I said

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it uses the locally validated notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if invalid notarizations are submitted, the dpowconfs "confirmations" stays at 1

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: Also what do you mean about the delay?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notarizer p2p protocol adds a delay before notarizing, usually 10 blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this allows the network to reach consensus normally and get 10 blocks deep

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a chain fork in parallel does not resolve after 10 blocks, then it seems there is a viable chain split happening and in such a case, the odds are very good that the notaries wont reach consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without the delay, it would allow evil notaries to get a chain that hasnt reached full consensus yet to be the notarized chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this seems to be most of the attack scenarios people have come up with.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we never had had any evil notary, let alone a majority colluding group of notaries, so this has not been any issue, but we could make it even theoretically impossible by requiring a 10 block (or 10 minutes worth) delay for a notarization to be valid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a bit nervous about such a change as i can see in some cases not all nodes will be in consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: "fixing" these theoretical attacks can actually make things worse....

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: Ah, interesting. So that'd also resolve the issue in a chain split where no notary is malicious, but they disagree because their node is synced to a different fork

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that case is already solved

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notaries run a stochastic protocol where the big majority needs to be in sync 100% or the notarization round fails

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we see during times of an ongoing 51% attack, the notarizations slow down or stop as the network splits, then when it resolves, notarizations start again

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is why we came up with dpowconfs, to allow nodes to detect the network problems and to not transact any large amounts during this time

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: How does the network resolve a major split, developer intervention/blessing of one side of the chain?

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: ie, does it require developers or someone talking to the notaries to get notarization back to operation?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the only case where that would be needed if two different chains get notarized, which is quite unlikely and even in such a case (it happened once due to not all notaries having updated in time for hardfork), eventually it resolves itself.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as long as the miners are extending the notarized chain, it resolves very quickly, faster than normal as once you switch to the notarized chain, you dont switch back.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is "sticky"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in the once case where multiple chains got notaries, we had all the notaries on the wrong chain to sync to the correct one and once that happened the rest of the network has an easier time to converge. but conflicting notarization is not anything that can be done without being notcied, it creates a messy situation

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: interesting. So in case of a chain split involving some programming bug that allowed both chains to be valid depending on network view. The devs could release some bug fix that invalidates the other fork. Notaries upgrade to that new wallet. They then begin notarizing the now only valid chain. Users with old software could then start seeing the notarizations and get pulled back onto the proper chain

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: Super interesting concept. Wonder if it could be exploited for a new type of fork in between soft and hard

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: Is there some communication channel for the notary nodes to be informed of a hard fork or other need to upgrade chain software?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, there are comms channels for notaries, it is its own sub-community that is quite active

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the incentives are setup for the notaries to want to notarize as much as possible

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so their game theory is to run the compatible notarizing p2p code

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: And these chain proofs... They're submitted to KMD network and then eventually make it into BTC. Does this work by BTC basically containing a proof of the overall KMD network? Or are multiple BTC proofs submitted for each blockchain/other notary operation? I assume the former, but just making sure

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: KMD notarizes to BTC which notarizes all tx on the KMD chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: other chains notarize to KMD via tx, which was notarized when KMD is notarized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, the former

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: That's what I was figuring. So to authenticate a proof on BTC, you'd also need to authenticate it on KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, the KMD notarization would have a BTC txid, which can be checked on BTC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://komodostats.com/api/notary/summary.json

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: look at that page

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: using info in the getinfo rpc call, you can find the required notarization txids

Content: the alternative is to have some dynamically updated process to update the notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but that would mean the dynamic update being 100% correct. maybe we can work on that together?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I had an initial implementation of ratifying a new slate, but that was 2 years ago and it wasnt reaching the ratification threshold, since then many notarizer aspects were improved so maybe it would work now, but we are doing annual hardforks for other things anyway

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: we have some tech that could be used for that. Unfortunately very poorly documented, but it's called decentralized governance protocol. Basically a way to change certain parameters on chain through a smart contract that implements voting.... The problem is who votes to change to the new keys and controls that power, even if it was restricted to only being changed at some certain time every year

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I used the notaries themselves to ratify the new slate of notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is why 50% of them are automatically reelected so we always have notaries who want to ratify the new slate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: definitely willing to work with you to get a dPoW2.0 for QTUM

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I guess for QTUM you would have the QTUM stakeholders to approve a new slate

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: Well if it's always pegged to Komodo, it'd make the most sense for the previous notaries to be the voters, maybe with 75% requirement or something like that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, they could vote on the QTUM blockchain using their pubkeys to be validated. ok, that works

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
@stefjazar following from beam.mw site (it is alternate implementation to grin):
BEAM will support around 17 transactions per second. While this number is higher than Bitcoin and existing privacy coins, it is important to emphasize that it is not high enough to use BEAM as means of exchange. In the future, it will be possible to improve transaction throughput by using a second layer out-of-chain solution such as Lightning, Thunderella or similar. Then you should be able to pay for your lattes with BEAM. Until then, BEAMâ€™s primary use case is store of value rather than day-to-day payments.

In BEAM, one block will be created approximately every minute. Each block will contain around 1000 transactions.

Instead of storing the full transaction history as in Bitcoin and other coins, a BEAM node only needs to store the current UTXO state, instead of entire transaction history. Validity of the history that brought us to this state can be confirmed by storing only the headers of the previous blocks which hold the proof of validity of previous states (using a structure called a Merkle tree) and Proof of Work that allows to reach consensus on which of the header chains should be considered the correct one in case of blockchain branching. This is achieved using cut-through, one of the core concepts in Mimblewimble.
We are still experimenting and evaluating, but it is a reasonable estimate that BEAM blockchain will be around 1/3 of Bitcoinâ€™s blockchain or less (assuming the same amount of activity).
